content: As an ERA (NOT in country)Vet, all the awards to the ENLISTED I saw , when the story was known were fully earned (tho a MSG won the Silver Star for attacking a VC .51 Russiam MG EMPLACEMENT WHILE IT WAS FIRING AT HIM, who told me had he not been suffering from incoming morter and RPG fire concussion , he never WOULD HAVE DONE IT) by the soldier. content: quote: I AM NOT trying to start crap with this post. I think so! Most Soldiers were more than a single instance and when something extraordinary happened, those recommending didn't just look at the isolated incident, they looked how that Soldier normally behaved. I didn't understand. You do think I was trying to start crap? Yes and No. I am a bit sensitive due to working with Soldiers and Vets. Sorry if I seem bitter. I have taken so much crap and seen so much given (Today OEF/OIF)about medals and citations. It is all perception of certain REMF's that have little knowledge of what took place. I provided Military Honors for a WWII Vet a few weeks ago. His only individual citation was a DSC. He personally killed 21 Germans and led his 6-man squad in capturing another 128 SS Troops. Not a member of his squad was wounded! I have contacted local Congress members to have it upgraded to MOH! So Far, not even a response to look into the matter. I have also worked with Soldiers who served in OIF (Activated NG) and found similar discrepencies. A Soldier on Patrol in Humvee took a large chunk of shrapnel in his leg, spent a few days in hospital, and along with hearing loss and TBI was released and retired. It took over 6 months to get him the PH - his only medal! Another from the same unit when helping out fellow Soldiers hit by IED was hit in face with a rock (over 6 inch in diameter) which broke nose, shattered some teeth, and cut up the face. He was denied a PH because "it was probably just an angry kid who threw it." In my personal case, was I more deserving of the citations I received because I carried the zippo on my back than the grunts along side who protected me so I could get into range? I try not to judge or compare actions (Even J. Kerry's) as I wasn't there and don't believe even with eye-witness acounts, there is enough information to make a judgement. I know the criteria and it seems more that meet the "Above and Beyond" are ignored or downgraded than receive the medals. It also seems that for whatever reasons, those that complain about who gets what are fellow Soldiers who know better! I'd trade every citation I ever earned, if just one more of my brothers would have been able to make it back to the world.

content: As an ERA (NOT in country)Vet, all the awards to the ENLISTED I saw , when the story was known were fully earned (tho a MSG won the Silver Star for attacking a VC .51 Russiam MG EMPLACEMENT WHILE IT WAS FIRING AT HIM, who told me had he not been suffering from incoming morter and RPG fire concussion , he never WOULD HAVE DONE IT) by the soldier. content: quote: I AM NOT trying to start crap with this post. I think so! Most Soldiers were more than a single instance and when something extraordinary happened, those recommending didn't just look at the isolated incident, they looked how that Soldier normally behaved. I didn't understand. You do think I was trying to start crap? Yes and No. I am a bit sensitive due to working with Soldiers and Vets. Sorry if I seem bitter. I have taken so much crap and seen so much given (Today OEF/OIF)about medals and citations. It is all perception of certain REMF's that have little knowledge of what took place. I provided Military Honors for a WWII Vet a few weeks ago. His only individual citation was a DSC. He personally killed 21 Germans and led his 6-man squad in capturing another 128 SS Troops. Not a member of his squad was wounded! I have contacted local Congress members to have it upgraded to MOH! So Far, not even a response to look into the matter. I have also worked with Soldiers who served in OIF (Activated NG) and found similar discrepencies. A Soldier on Patrol in Humvee took a large chunk of shrapnel in his leg, spent a few days in hospital, and along with hearing loss and TBI was released and retired. It took over 6 months to get him the PH - his only medal! Another from the same unit when helping out fellow Soldiers hit by IED was hit in face with a rock (over 6 inch in diameter) which broke nose, shattered some teeth, and cut up the face. He was denied a PH because "it was probably just an angry kid who threw it." In my personal case, was I more deserving of the citations I received because I carried the zippo on my back than the grunts along side who protected me so I could get into range? I try not to judge or compare actions (Even J. Kerry's) as I wasn't there and don't believe even with eye-witness acounts, there is enough information to make a judgement. I know the criteria and it seems more that meet the "Above and Beyond" are ignored or downgraded than receive the medals. It also seems that for whatever reasons, those that complain about who gets what are fellow Soldiers who know better! I'd trade every citation I ever earned, if just one more of my brothers would have been able to make it back to the world.
